Award.AwardTitle: Petrologic and Chronologic Evaluation of Himalayan Tectonic Models in Southern Bhutan
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the pressure-temperature-time evolution of metamorphic rocks exposed in southern Bhutan is being investigated to test models of collisional orogenesis. In most areas of the Himalaya, low-grade Tethyan rocks are juxtaposed with high-grade Greater Himalayan rocks along a ductile extensional structure, the South Tibetan Detachment. In the Shemgang region of Bhutan, however, a recent study instead proposes an intact stratigraphic section from Greater Himalayan to Tethyan rocks. If correct, this model strongly limits the importance of two models of crustal deformation behavior during collisional orogenesis, and further implies a normal chronologic, thermal and baric gradient across the Greater Himalayan - Tethyan contact. New data are being collected on pressure-temperature conditions from garnet-bearing rocks, and on metamorphic ages from monazite-bearing rocks. The new data will identify whether the section is indeed chronologically and metamorphically intact, testing the stratigraphic model, and provide crucial new constraints on Himalayan metamorphism and deformation behavior.

This research addresses the fundamental problem of how continental crust behaves during collisions: does it flow (in a pipe-flow sense) weakly towards areas of focused erosion, or does it behave in a stronger more rigid fashion? While this debate originated in the Himalaya and is actively studied there, it has been widely applied to other collisional mountain belts. Thus new results are of broad interest to the geologic community. New chronologic and petrologic methods of investigating metamorphic rocks are being more generally developed, expanding applications to other rock types and orogens.

This project supports the post-doctoral training of a recent female PhD, improving representation of women in the geosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to investigate the evolution of the eastern Himalaya mountains of Bhutan using the geochemistry and geochronology of metamorphic rocks. Two endmember models for mountain belt formation have evolved in the past decade, whose predictions differ critically in this region. Our work involved collecting and interpreting chemical compositions of metamorphic minerals to infer pressures and temperatures of formation. The main distinctive dichotomy in testing models is the occurrence of continuous pressures and temperatures through a thick section of rock vs. temperature and/or pressure discontinuities. Discontinuities would link the evolution of these rocks with major shear zones to the north and indicate long-lasting, far-reaching structures, whereas the absence of discontinuities would argue for local control of structures.

Our primary result shows no pressure or temperature discontinuities through the analyzed section, but imply that the section was originally twice as thick as it is now. This indicates that thinning has occurred, but not along specific shear zones, and supports models of local extensional shear effects. This work has been published in the peer-reviewed literature, and presented at numerous conferences and lectures.

A second major result looked at the chronology of metamorphism along a major thrust system. By linking the chronology of individual chemical domains in the mineral monazite (a trace phosphate in many rocks) and to the temperature of monazite formation, we were able to estimate the rate of thrust movement. Between 15 and 20 million years ago, this rate was nearly two times higher than the long term convergence rate or the modern rate as estimated using satellites. This result builds on a body of evidence that mountain belts evolve discontinuously, with times of rapid movement on faults and times of slower movement.

Every project has ancillary research endeavors and outcomes, mainly directed towards understanding what controls our signals. In this study we encountered an unexpected, unrecognized problem relating to past work investigating the origin of granites and their relationship to regional metamorphism. Previous studies have assumed the granites are directly linked to heating processes. However, granite temperatures, as inferred using trace element thermometers, indicate the granites are much cooler. We do not know why these discrepancies occur. A statement of the problem is published in the peer-reviewed literature, and is an area of current investigation.

Last, we are developing a new technique for determining the pressures and temperatures of mineral formation. Many large metamorphic minerals contain inclusions of other minerals. Using Raman spectroscopy and precise knowledge of how mineral volumes respond to pressure and temperature, we can recover the pressures (and sometimes temperatures) at which a mineral inclusion was engulfed by its surrounding host. This approach has been used previously to investigate mineral inclusions in diamond, but is rarely applied to garden-variety metamorphic rocks.

This grant directly supported the research and educational activities of 1 post-doctoral researcher, 1 undergraduate student, and 2 graduate students. Rocks from this study were also used in two classroom projects at Boise State University, teaching mineralogy and petrology, with outreach to approximately 40 undergraduate geology majors. Research results have been publicized through numerous public and institutional outreach activities, both in the US and abroad. Key among these is the activity of the PI as a Distinguished Lecturer for the Mineralogical Society of America (2012-2013), culminating in the Shell London Lecture, sponsored by the Geological Society of London. This lecture ("Making the Himalaya: Oozing, squashing or sliding?" is available on YouTube.
